Ky. revenue shortfall of $135M predicted, but..

First quarter's limp state revenues portend shortage, but second quarter starts strong

Ky. revenue shortfall of $135M predicted, but..

Politics

Tom Loftus, The Courier-Journal 6:05 a.m. EST November 11, 2014
Buy Photo

Kentucky Governor Steve Beshear(Photo: 2014 C-J file photo by Michael Clevenger)Buy Photo

Tags

  • Steve Beshear
71 CONNECT 10 TWEET 2 LINKEDIN 6 COMMENTEMAILMORE

A delayed State Budget Office report predicted on Monday that Kentucky's state budget will suffer a $135 million revenue shortfall when the fiscal year ends on June 30, 2015.

But that report was based on the outlook after the first three quarters of this fiscal year and its grim outlook was mitigated somewhat by the office's separate report of receipts for the month of October - which showed some recovery.

So what's the outlook for Kentucky balancing its budget this year without spending cuts?

"There's no reason at this point to panic," Gov. Steve Beshear said Monday. October's receipts are encouraging, he said, and his staff will continue to monitor revenues for the time being before any action may be needed.

The quarterly report was based on July-August-September revenues - which were weak: only 1.1% growth over the first quarter of last year. The current state budget requires 3.6 percent revenue growth for this entire year.

COURIER-JOURNAL

More state budget cuts?

The first quarter's results were expected to result in a prediction for a shortfall, and indeed they did. The quarterly report anticipates some improvement in revenue growth the rest of this fiscal year, but not enough, and it estimates actual General Fund revenues for the full year will total $9.666 billion.

That's $135 million short of the $9.801 billion required by the budget.

As this quarterly report was released, however, the budget office released receipts for October, and they were pretty strong.

General Fund revenues last month grew a healthy 4.6 percent over revenues of October of 2013.

And now, through one third of the year, revenues have grown 1.9 percent over the first third of last fiscal year.

This improvement needs to continue, though. General Fund revenues must grow 4.4 percent over the final eight months of the fiscal year to reach the budget's requirement of $9.801 billion.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Budget shortfall raises spending cut fears in Ky.

"October was clearly a strong month..." Budget Director Jane Driskell said in the monthly report. "The main contributions to the healthy growth in October were the individual income tax and the sales taxes, which grew at 4.8 percent and 6.3 percent respectively while corporate and property receipts continue to underperform."

The quarterly report with its gloomy forecast was due - by law - 30 days after the close of the quarter, or Oct. 30. And while my review of past reports shows some were a day or two late, I've never seen one 11 days late.

Driskell said Monday that the time was needed for additional research - checking of numbers and trends.

But the delay put release of the report off - from the week before the Nov. 4 elections until the week after.

Beshear, however, insisted Monday that there was "no hidden agenda" behind the delay.
